there are lots of service unit file has this ntp-config, we need to remove this dependency.

```
lgh@gulv-vm1:/data2/sonic/stretch/sonic-buildimage$ git grep ntp-config
files/build_templates/bgp.service.j2:Before=ntp-config.service
files/build_templates/dhcp_relay.service.j2:Before=ntp-config.service
files/build_templates/lldp.service.j2:Before=ntp-config.service
files/build_templates/ntp-config.timer:Unit=ntp-config.service
files/build_templates/pmon.service.j2:Before=ntp-config.service
files/build_templates/radv.service.j2:Before=ntp-config.service
files/build_templates/snmp.service.j2:Before=ntp-config.service
files/build_templates/sonic_debian_extension.j2:sudo cp $IMAGE_CONFIGS/ntp/ntp-config.service $FILESYSTEM_ROOT/etc/systemd/system/
files/build_templates/sonic_debian_extension.j2:sudo LANG=C chroot $FILESYSTEM_ROOT systemctl enable ntp-config.service
files/build_templates/sonic_debian_extension.j2:sudo cp $IMAGE_CONFIGS/ntp/ntp-config.sh $FILESYSTEM_ROOT/usr/bin/
files/build_templates/sonic_debian_extension.j2:sudo cp $BUILD_TEMPLATES/ntp-config.timer $FILESYSTEM_ROOT/etc/systemd/system/
files/build_templates/sonic_debian_extension.j2:sudo LANG=C chroot $FILESYSTEM_ROOT systemctl enable ntp-config.timer
files/build_templates/swss.service.j2:Before=ntp-config.service
files/build_templates/syncd.service.j2:Before=ntp-config.service
files/build_templates/teamd.service.j2:Before=ntp-config.service
files/build_templates/telemetry.service.j2:Before=ntp-config.service
files/image_config/ntp/ntp-config.service:ExecStart=/usr/bin/ntp-config.sh
```
@lguohan by reverting #2494, we didn't remove ntp-config.service. we only removed the 5 minutes delay.
Made to 201811 branch on 2/21/2019
Joe, I agree with you. Reverting the original PR is a cleaner way of managing git history.

@nikos-github the problem is that when ntpd is running without -x option, it is allowed to make a clock adjustment when it first connected to a NTP server. Which could result in dialing back the clock by x amount of time. If supervisord is starting a process when this happens, supervisord would barf. -g allows ntpd to dial clock back/forth when the difference is greater than 1000 seconds. We thought that could cause same supervisord issue.

@yxieca @lguohan This is like the 4th PR to change something else in order to address the supervisord shortcomings with the clock adjusting. Not allowing the clock to jump, means that the clock is not synchronized for a large period of time. I really don't understand how it is an acceptable solution to have the clock drift like that especially since it can take hours or even days to catch up. This isn't the right way to address the issue at supervisord and we discussed this before. And yet here we are 4 PRs later.

@nikos-github Acknowledge. I agree that we are trying to work-around known issues with these changes. We would like to see supervisord bug get fixed too. But until then, we would rather like not triggering the issue :-)
@yxieca Have you tested with your changes to see how long it takes for the clock to synchronize if the difference is 1000s of seconds?
@nikos-github from what I observed, the clock fixing rate is about 70 seconds every 24 hours.
@yxieca @lguohan So we're taking many many days. How is that ok? I can tell you right now this will be a deployment blocker for any of our sonic customers.

Can you please explain why we need to do this?

@nikos-github: This is to prevent overloading remote syslog servers if a process starts spamming the syslog. For example, if certain ASICs present a parity error that does not get auto-corrected, the syncd container can be responsible for sending > 200,000 syslog messages every 5 minutes.

@jleveque What is the effect of this on debug level setting on daemons in containers? How did you determine the numbers? Are they meant to be per PID? If so, it implies that we think 30 msgs per second for a PID is the limit. Is that actually enough at boot time? Why not implement the rate limiting at the source/syncd for the example event that you mentioned or filter it and not send it to syslog server once you know what to look for? I'm not convinced this is the right approach since there are valid cases where we may want to generate and see more than 30 msgs per second from a PID.

@nikos-github: 

> What is the effect of this on debug level setting on daemons in containers?

Debug level settings were not taken into effect for this PR. This PR is based off the level of log messages of an image built with current default settings.

> How did you determine the numbers? Are they meant to be per PID?

The numbers are not per-PID, but rather _per-container_. The numbers were an average of a few switches configured with 120+ ports. During normal operation, the highest rate of messages occurs at boot. I found with these devices, the average maximum rate of _total_ messages (base image + all containers) is ~12,000 per 5 minute interval. The average maximum rate per container at boot is as follows:

| Container | Max Messages Per 5-Minute Interval |
| --- | --- |
| syncd | 3871 |
| swss | 2761 |
| teamd | 2097 |
| lldp | 415 |
| snmp | 325 |
| pmon | 110 |
| dhcp_relay | 67 |
| bgp | 31 |
| radv | 13 |
| database | 9 |

Thus, setting the per-container rate limit to 10,000 messages per 5-minute interval should not interfere with boot messages. If we are concerned at all, I think we could increase the limit to 20,000 or even a bit higher. The idea here is simply to prevent a rogue process from spamming a remote syslog server, so there is a bit of flexibility.

@yxieca Fast reboot is supported on mellanox. In case of fast reboot WARM_BOOT variable is false so it still stops the module - this is how it was before the change, so I don't understand how this change affects fast reboot
@stepanblyschak oh my bad. I was looking at change in the mindset of warm-reboot script. The comments explains all and your test is sufficient.

Retest this please

@renukamanavalan: More info with regards to what? The reason the process exited? If so, Supervisor already logs this info upon process exit. For example, `INFO exited: orchagent (terminated by SIGSEGV (core dumped); not expected)`.

The changes looks good to me, per my little knowledge on the system. 

Personally, I would need to understand more at higher level. For example, the script wait_for_intf.sh (both old & current) waits forever, until the IF is up. Wonder what would happen if interface init has failed and reporting some error, which would need some explicit action to fix, at the system level. Like, what logs gets fired and what auto-mitigation happens or possibilities for such ...
Please do not close pull request. Please use the "Review changes" feature to add a review, either approving or requesting changes. PR owner or repo maintainer will merge PR once approved.

Sorry for closing, by mistake.

I don't have any request for any code changes. I will leave approval to Guohan, as I am still learning the system.

Regarding the wait_for_intf.sh script, this is to ensure all interfaces required by the processes in the container are up and ready before starting them to ensure they do not get into a bad state. Auto-mitigation should be handled outside of this container, by orchagent or a related process.
Are you planning to make similar change for master/201811 branches?  We may even consider unplanned warm restart support beyond this.

@jipanyang: Yes, a similar change will be made to the master/201811 branches. The changes are a bit more complex due to warm reboot. After this PR is merged, I will begin work on a solution for those branches.

One known issue with stretch build is that, even with "make list" or "BLDENV=stretch make list",  it tries to build all missing deb and dockers for strecth.  Guess we could fix that in future.
@jipanyang: Was there a reason not to upgrade `REDIS_VERSION` to the current Stretch default version, `3.2.6-3+deb9u2`?
I do not think so. 3.2.4 still have bugs we should upgrade.
@jleveque @lguohan  I didn't pay attention to redis version.   Yes, it should be upgraded to stretch default version.  Are there critical bugs with 3.2.4?

Is going straight to 3.2.13 better?
https://raw.githubusercontent.com/antirez/redis/3.2/00-RELEASENOTES
agree

@jipanyang: As long as the Debian packaging is available for version 3.2.13, we can do it.

Actually, it looks like the current version available from [stretch-backports](https://packages.debian.org/search?suite=stretch-backports&section=all&arch=any&searchon=names&keywords=redis) is 5.0.3-3~bpo9+2. We could potentially upgrade even further, to this version.

@jleveque  redis is built with packages stored in sonicstorage.blob.core.windows.net https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/blob/master/src/redis/Makefile#L16,  could you handle the package repo update and version upgrade together?

> port index start from 1.
z9100 sfputils.py the port starts from 0.
port index is used to identify the front panel port, if z9100 front panel port start from 1, then port index should start 1.

> port index is used to identify the front panel port, if z9100 front panel port start from 1, then port index should start 1.
I agree that ONIE standard numbering is from 1 (https://opencomputeproject.github.io/onie/design-spec/hw_requirements.html), We see that other vendors have started with 0 (including dell S6100). Does the physical index of port correspond to silkscreen (https://github.com/Azure/SONiC/wiki/Porting-Guide). Otherwise we and all implementations will have to change sfputils.py plugin to decrement the port index. Can you please clarify?

Hi @MichelMoriniaux, check this out https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/pull/2593
cool!

@jleveque before we merge this PR just want to clarify that we will have both old and new APIs supported while the daemon will continue using the old APIs.
Do you know what is the plan to have new APIs supported by other vendors so we will be able to do the change in the daemon and remove the old API support. We will reduce maintenance on different code base.

@liat-grozovik: Yes. We intend for the daemons to continue using the old API until all vendors have provided implementations of the new API, at which point we will refactor the daemons to use the new API and deprecate the old.
Made to 201811 branch on 2/14/2019

@zhenggen-xu 

I did 'git grep' in sonic-buildiamge, sonic-utilities, sonic-platform-common, sonic-quagga, sonic-frr, I didn't see anyone updating this file. In sonic-buildimage, it is used as an initial template.

It might be reasonable to move this file under /usr/share/sonic/template instead (in a different PR).

Unless I missed something in sub modules that I didn't check, the usage of this file is very limited and should not be copied forward. Whatever effect this file has in the old image has been captured in config_db.

Please let me know your opinion.

Regards,
Ying

@yxieca It is not necessarily updated by SONiC code. I would think this file should be downloaded as part of initial configuration (like ZTP).  But during the upgrade process, I still think we should keep the old file so we have the same configuration.  This file is used in conjunction with config_db data to generate the bgp configuration:
sonic-cfggen -d -y /etc/sonic/deployment_id_asn_map.yml -t /usr/share/sonic/templates/bgpd.conf.j2 > /etc/quagga/bgpd.conf
@lguohan  Can you comment on this PR so we can close the discussion?

@lguohan  As talked,  I removed the deployment_id_asn_map.yml from the restore file list, we will rely on the fact that we should keep this file backwards compatible from image to image, but the file could get upgraded.
Made to 201811 branch on 2/2/2019
